Response.BaseQuestion: What is a clinical trial?
Response.Content: Clinical research is often conducted by means of a "clinical trial" defined by The United States National Institute of Health (NIH) as "one type of clinical research that follows a pre-defined plan or protocol." A clinical trial is scientifically controlled study of the safety and effectiveness of investigational treatments and devices for various diseases and conditions. These trials determine if treatments are safe to use and will improve the health of people. Before a medication, therapy, or medical device can be made available to the general public, it has to go through several phases of clinical research. There are also observational studies, in which people who have a certain condition or disease or who receive a particular treatment are followed, or observed, over time and compared with another group of people who are not affected by the condition.

Response.BaseQuestion: What agency regulates clinical trials?
Response.Content: Clinical trials in the United States are regulated by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in the United States. The role of the FDA is to ensure adherence to a set of principles known as good clinical practices, or GCPs. These principles are designed to enhance the quality of clinical trial data, as well as to ensure the protection of study participants like you.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the phases of a clinical trial?
Response.Content: Clinical trials are typically performed in "phases." These phases are designed to build evidence that an investigational treatment will be beneficial to patients with a particular disease or condition.Before a medication can be tested in human subjects, pre-clinical testing occurs in a lab environment to gather data on whether the investigational treatment has the potential to work in treating the disease. Next, the therapy transitions to a Phase I clinical trial, which typically involves a small number of healthy patients and is designed to test whether the experimental treatment is safe and to determine what dose should be given. If the results show that the treatment is safe, it will transition into Phase II clinical trials, where it will be tested in patients with the disease or condition to see whether the treatment has any effect on this disease. The overall safety of the drug will also continue to be assessed. If the therapy works to treat a disease, it will enter Phase III trials, which involve a large number of patients to assess the effectiveness of the new treatment and how it compares to existing therapies, if applicable. And again, the overall safety of the drug will continue to be assessed.Often times, more than one trial will be conducted in Phase II and Phase III, although this is not always the case.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the types of clinical trials?
Response.Content: There are two main types of clinical trials: Placebo-controlled and head-to-head trials.A placebo-controlled trial means that one group of patients will receive the treatment to be evaluated, while a second group, often known as the control group, will receive a placebo treatment. This placebo often looks just like the experimental treatment but is designed to have no real effect on patients. Placebos are often used in blinded trials, which are trials where the patients do not know whether they are receiving the real or placebo treatment; this is done to account for the "placebo effect," which is what the effect of participation in the study that does not result from the therapy itself is called.It's also important to note that placebo trials are usually, but not always, done where no standard of care or FDA-approved treatment exists.In a head-to-head or comparative effectiveness trial, one group of patients receives the treatment to be evaluated, while a second group of patients receives a different therapy. In most cases, the other therapy, or comparator, is a treatment that is already commonly used by patients. This is often referred to as the "standard of care." These types of trials allow researchers to see how the experimental therapy performs in comparison to other therapies.When discussing clinical trials, you might notice that they can also be referred to as "single-blind" or "double-blind." A single-blind trial means that the investigators involved in the trial know whether the patient is getting the investigational treatment, but the patient is not aware. In a double-blind trial, neither the investigator nor the patient knows who is receiving the investigational therapy. By "blinding" the trials, no biases--whether real or unintentional--are introduced into the trial.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a Data Safety and Monitoring Committee?
Response.Content: A Data Safety and Monitoring Committee, sometimes known as a Data and Safety Monitoring Board, is an independent group of experts who monitor patient safety and treatment efficacy data during the course of a clinical trial. The group, which typically includes 3 to 10 members, is authorized to recommend that a trial be stopped due to safety concerns, because the treatment is not effective, or if the new treatment is so beneficial that it should be immediately considered for approval. Members of the Data Safety and Monitoring Committee are not related to the institution or company conducting or sponsoring the trial and are usually made up of clinicians with knowledge of the disease or condition being treated, statisticians, and sometimes a patient advocacy representative.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is an Institutional Review Board (IRB)?
Response.Content: An Institutional Review Board, or ethical review board, is a committee charged with approving, monitoring and reviewing clinical research involving humans. The main goal of the board is to make sure the study is ethical and the rights and welfare of participants are protected. This includes making sure that research risks are minimized and are reasonable in relation to any potential benefits, among other things. Prior to the start of the clinical trial, this committee will conduct a risk- benefit analysis to determine whether the research should be performed.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a clinical trial protocol?
Response.Content: A protocol is a written document outlining the study research plan. A clinical trial protocol is designed to answer specific research questions, as well as safeguard the health of participants. In general, a protocol describes an overview of the trial objectives; what types of people may participate; the number of participants needed for the trial, the schedule of tests, procedures, medications, and dosages; the length of the trial; and what information will be gathered about participants.

Response.BaseQuestion: Are placebos ethical?
Response.Content: Patients participating in a placebo-controlled clinical trial are told during the informed-consent process that there is a chance that they could receive the investigational treatment or an inactive placebo while participating in the study. A placebo often looks like the investigational medication, but it has no active ingredient in it. Placebos are used in clinical research to help evaluate the effectiveness of an investigational medication. Because some participants receive the inactive placebo, the researchers can see the affect the investigational medication has in those who take it. Using a placebo during a study is ethical because the patient has been informed that there is a possibility that they will be receiving no treatment. It is also important to note that depending on the disease, an approved standard of care therapy may not exist. Therefore, if you are participating in a study that has a placebo, the placebo may actually be the standard of care.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is informed consent?
Response.Content: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration requires that potential study participants be given complete information about the planned trial under a process known as "informed consent." This process is designed to accurately inform individuals of the purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to the clinical trial; ensure that participants understand this information and how it relates to their own health or interests; and provides an opportunity for an individual to make a voluntary decision about whether to participate in the study.Once you have had enough time to read and understand the informed consent form and had time to discuss with the study doctor, you can choose to participate in the trial by signing a written informed consent form. Even if you sign the form, you can still withdraw from the study at any time, for any reason.

Response.BaseQuestion: What rights do I have if I participate in a clinical trial? Can I quit the clinical trial at any time? Will the risks/side effects be explained to me?
Response.Content: If you participate in a clinical trial, you are guaranteed certain right that may be referred to as a "Bill of Rights." Taking part in a clinical trial is your decision, and it affords you certain rights. For example, the Clinical Trial Volunteer's Bill of Rights states that you be given enough time to decide whether to participate and to make that decision without any pressure from the people who are doing the research; that you can refuse to participate in the study and to stop participating at any time; and that your decision not to participate will not affect your right to your usual care not related to the research. In addition, this bill of rights states that you have the right to be told why the clinical trial is being done, what will happen, and what you will be asked to do if you are in the trial, as well as to be informed of any reasonably foreseeable risks, discomforts, or side effects that may occur during the trial and who will pay for any research-related treatment. This bill of rights also empowers you to have your questions answered by the research team at any time and requires that you receive a copy of your signed Informed Consent form.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is being tested in this trial? What is the purpose of this trial?
Response.Content: The purpose of this trial is to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of an investigational medication called tolvaptan in patients with late stage 2 to early stage 4 chronic kidney disease caused by autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, or ADPKD. For people with ADPKD, the kidneys respond abnormally to the hormone vasopressin, which may be involved in cyst development or growth in humans. The investigational medication is designed to interfere with or block the effect of vasopressin on the kidneys. The purpose of this trial is to test how useful tolvaptan will be in treating ADPKD. You are being asked to take part in this study because you have been diagnosed with late stage 2 and to early stage 4 chronic kidney disease caused by ADPKD.

Response.BaseQuestion: Is this drug being used to treat any other conditions?
Response.Content: Although tolvaptan is still considered experimental in the treatment of ADPKD, it was approved in the United States in 2009 for the treatment of patients with certain types of hyponatremia, which is a low amount of sodium or salt in the blood. It was also recently approved in Japan for the treatment of ADPKD and is now being studied in several other countries in the REPRISE study as a potential treatment for ADPKD.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the exclusions?
Response.Content: This study will not enroll patients who have liver damage other than that expected for ADPKD. Nor will it enroll those patients who have evidence of significant renal diseases, recent renal surgery, acute kidney injury, or who are already on dialysis. The study is also not seeking to enroll patients with advanced diabetes or who have a limited ability to urinate. In addition, you should not plan to join the trial if you are pregnant, are planning to become pregnant, or are currently breastfeeding. You should not join this trial if you have had a bad reaction to tolvaptan in the past or if you have had a bad reaction to benzazapine derivatives, such as benazepril, mirtazapine, conivaptan, and fenoldopam mesylate. If you are unsure of whether you are eligible to enroll in the trial, please ask the study doctor.

Response.BaseQuestion: What will the treatment entail? Administration method? Dose?
Response.Content: For the majority of the time you are participating in the study, you will be randomly assigned to receive either tolvaptan or placebo. "Randomly assigned" means that you will be assigned by chance, like the toss of a coin, to receive either tolvaptan or placebo. Your chance of receiving either tolvaptan or placebo is 50 percent. Once you have been randomly assigned to treatment, neither you, your study doctor, nor Otsuka Pharmaceutical Development and Commercialization, Inc. will know if you are taking tolvaptan or placebo Both tolvaptan and placebo are an oral tablet that is self-administered once upon wakening and again approximately 8 to 9 hours later. During a small portion of the treatment period, you will be exposed to tolvaptan and placebo and may be switched back and forth between treatments at different times for defined intervals. You will also go through a short phase where you will be given gradually increasing doses of the investigational medication but you will not be told whether it is tolvaptan or placebo. The study doctor may adjust the dosage over the course of the treatment period based on your reaction to tolvaptan or placebo.

Response.BaseQuestion: How long will the trial last?
Response.Content: In total, the study will last approximately 15 months from start to finish. You will enter a 1- to 2- week screening period where study staff will determine whether you meet the qualifications to enroll in the trial. The screening period may be extended up to an additional 8 weeks if needed to allow you to adjust to changes made in certain medications or to repeat certain blood tests. Once you have successfully enrolled in the trial, you will enter the treatment period of the study and will be given either placebo or tolvaptan during the next 13 to 14 months. Finally, once you have stopped taking the study medication you will enter the follow-up period, which will last for 3 weeks.

Response.BaseQuestion: Will my name be publically used during the study or when the results are published?
Response.Content: Any data collected about you as part of a clinical trial is subject to the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, or HIPAA, Privacy Rule. This rule establishes the conditions under which protected health information may be used or disclosed by groups for research purposes. Under this rule, your research team can publish, present, or otherwise disclose data on you for research purposes and only after it has been de-identified, meaning that there is no way that anyone outside of the study could know that it is you. As such, your name will never be publicly revealed in connection with the study.OPDC personnel and its designees including central laboratory, study monitors, and auditors, the Institutional Review Board or Ethics Committee overseeing this study and the regulatory authorities, including the FDA, will have access to your health records and test results containing your personal information. If you choose to use the visiting nurse option, the visiting nurse, visiting nurse agency, and the visiting nurse service provider will have access to your individually identifiable protected health information. Also, for safety reasons, if the study doctor is unable to locate you, an independent firm (contracted by OPDC) may be hired to assist the study doctor in locating you or information regarding your health status. The firm will only be given limited information necessary to locate you.
